app.note: BS's reading and emendation abhīṣṭhāya makes no sense. I suspect that the omission of the second iteration of māna is a typographic error in BS's edition rather than a scribal error in the original, since BS do not supply these characters, and the line is shorter than expected without them.

I restore conjecturally. Reading -nirasta-ketūddyotita- would be closer to the reported reading, but would not be very intelligible. Compare ripu-timira-vidhvaṁsane pralayādityaḥ, said of a later Viṣṇuvardhana in line 14 of the Pr̥thivipallavapaṭṭana grant.

My conjectural restoration is highly tentative. I believe it corresponds fairly well to purport of the passage, but the actual inscribed word may have been very different (e.g. -navakarmmotsarpanārtthaṁ?). I cannot interpret PS's reading/emendation and cannot accept his interpretation, for which see the note to the translation. The ARIE report says the grant's purposes included navakarmasaraṇa.
PS's use of the double hyphen for transliterated characters belonging to a single akṣara is unreliable, so the text may be -nadyāt; conceivably, this may also be a misreading of -nadyāḥ or -nadyāḫ.

In PS's edition, this word is set with a line break after jemanū and a large space after r. I assume, but may be mistaken, that his author manuscript used the Telugu character ṟ here, which the typesetter of the paper messed up.
I assume that PS's unclear da at the beginning of line 20 is in fact dda, but if the neighbouring ablative endings are indeed written with final T, then -grāmāt dakṣiṇe is also conceivable.

In PS's edition, this word is set with a line break after na and a large space after l. I assume, but may be mistaken, that his author manuscript used the Telugu character ḻ here, which the typesetter of the paper messed up.

In PS's edition, this word is set with a line break after Inte and a large space after r. I assume, but may be mistaken, that his author manuscript used the Telugu character ṟ here, which the typesetter of the paper messed up.
The ARIE report gives this name as Pattipāka, along with the possible alternative Pattipāḍu.
Given that a lacuna follows, the last line on the plate is probably damaged. The inscribed text may be the expected dattaM or, more correctly for the syntax, dattavāN.

PS does not indicate the size of the lacuna; if the length of the horizontal line representing it is an indication, then it corresponds to about two akṣaras. Given the length of the preceding lines, my conjectural restoration of five characters is feasible, but near the upper end of the possible size range.

In PS's edition, this word is set with a line break after Ita and a large space after h. I assume, but may be mistaken, that his author manuscript used an upadhmānīya here, which the typesetter of the paper messed up.

In PS's edition, this word is set with a line break after rājabhir, continued in the next line, after a large indent, with an = sign in front of the next word.I assume, but may be mistaken, that his author manuscript used an upadhmānīya here, which the typesetter of the paper messed up.
I restore this stanza on the basis of the Koṇḍaṇagūru grant of Indra Bhaṭṭāraka. Given PS's very divergent reading, the first word may in fact be different.

app.note: I duplicate PS's text to the letter here (aside from the transliteration convention), since I cannot guess what the original may have been. I strongly doubt this reading. The ARIE report also believes that the grant is dated to the first regnal year, read there as prathamavarṣam.

Here too I adopt all characters as read by PS, with slight and straightforward changes to the hyphenation. The ARIE report cites part of this sentence as Āṇatī svamukham. I have doubts about the phrase ubhaya-gaṇa-, but cannot offer a plausible alternative (would mukha-yogena be any better?).

div.head: Plates
div.p: Greetings from the encampment at Vijayavāṭa. From the ocean that is the lineage of the majestic Caḷukyas—who are of the Mānavya gotra which is praised by the entire world, who were deliberately appointed to kingship by Lord Mahāsena, who attained kingship by the grace of Kauśikī’s boon, who acquired the superior Boar emblem by the grace of the divine Nārāyaṇa, and whose bodies have been hallowed through washing in the purificatory ablutions avabhr̥tha of the Aśvamedha sacrifice—had arisen a moon who was His Majesty King mahārāja Viṣṇuvardhana, who earned his great good reputation by his political acumen naya , discipline vinaya and valour. His son was His Majesty King mahārāja Jayasiṁha I. His dear younger brother was Indra Bhaṭṭāraka, whose body was adorned by a host of virtues such as selflessness, generosity, profundity and beauty, who had by his own valour conquered the circle of the earth and whose valour equalled Indra’s. His dear son, His Majesty the supremely pious King mahārāja Viṣamasiddhi Viṣṇuvardhana II—who was deliberately appointed as heir by his mother and father, whose pair of feet are tinted by the hues of the rays from the many gems fitted to the surfaces of the crowns of enemy kings bowed down by the blade of his sword, a blazing doomsday sun by his way of dispelling the darkness of the Kali age—has, according to the religious dharma- instruction of His Reverence Master ācārya Kanakanandi, a forehead mark on the Vr̥kṣamūla Yāpanīya gaṇa, in order to increase his own merit dharma , granted the village Pattipoka in Potupa district viṣaya , to the east of the river Eli, to the south of the village Jemanūṟuva, to the west of the village Naḻpuru, to the north of the village Inteṟu—thus situated in the midst of these—to the Jain temple located in KasumiThe vowels of this name are uncertainly reported. The place may be identical to Kasimi in the other set of Peddāpurappāḍu plates. for offering Mahābali, Caru and Vaiśvādeva to the Reverend Arhats and for carrying out renovation nava-karman .Although I can only tentatively restore part of this phrase (see the apparatus to line 18), I am quite certain that it concerns renovation. PS apparently reads navakarmmasaranetrī, emends to navakarmmasāranetrī, then in his discussion subtly retains only navakarmma-sāra, which he considers to be a reference to nine works apparently called sāras by a Jaina author Koṇḍakundācārya. I utterly fail to see why these works would be mentioned in the context.

Let no-one pose an obstacle to the enjoyment of their rights over it. This grant should be protected by the kings of countries that come into existence hereafter. In this connection the following stanzas were sung by Vyāsa:
Many kings have granted land, and many have preserved it as formerly granted. Whosoever at any time owns the land, the fruit reward accrued of granting it belongs to him at that time.
One who takes away income vr̥tti sanctioned aṅkita by a royal decree śāsana incurs the fate of one who murders his lord, cows, Brahmins, children, women or ascetics.

This ruling dharma was the first year. The execution aṇati is by the king’s own mouth. It is to be protected by both groups. Prosperity!If correctly read, these last sentences of the grant are very poorly worded and are not always clear.

PS gives no physical description and mentions no seal. I include the seal text on the basis of the ARIE report, which however does not mention the word śrī in the seal. I add this on the assumption that it is present as usual, but I may be mistaken.

A ), without facsimiles and without translation. The present edition by Dániel Balogh is based on the published edition. However, this edition contains such an inordinate number of typographic (or other) mistakes, that duplicating it to the letter would serve no purpose, and in some cases the intent of the editors cannot be reconstructed. My edition therefore shows my conjectures of what the actual reading of the plates may be and how that should in my opinion be emended. Every locus where my "reading" of the assumed original diverges from the printed edition is marked up as unclear and tentative in my edition, whereas loci marked as unclear by the original editors are shown here as unclear, but confidently read. My apparatus cites the printed edition where I deviate from it in a major way or where my conjecture is uncertain, but I silently correct some obvious typos, ignore some nonsensical emendations, and apply my own segmentation.
